message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest that he may have developed antibiotic-associated diarrhea, which can be caused by Clostridium difficile infection. The pathogenic mechanism of Clostridium difficile involves the production of toxins that can modify or inactivate host cell proteins, including the glucosylation of Rho family GTPases. This can lead to disruption of the actin cytoskeleton and ultimately cell death, resulting in the symptoms observed in this patient. Options B, C, and D are not associated with the pathogenic mechanism of Clostridium difficile infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms coupled with the history of treatment with clindamycin suggests the presence of Clostridium difficile infection. The pathogenic mechanism of C. difficile involves the release of toxins that causes glucosylation of Rho family GTPases, disrupting the actin cytoskeleton and causing inflammation and damage to the colonic mucosa. Option B is the mechanism of action for Diptheria toxin, option C is for Cholera toxin, and option D is for alpha-toxin of Clostridium perfringens.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a Clostridium difficile infection, which is caused by the toxin-mediated damage to the colonic mucosa. Among the options, only ADP-ribosylation of Gs-alpha subunit of G-protein coupled receptors and cell membrane degradation by lecithinase are mechanisms of other bacterial toxins, and not related to C. difficile. Inactivation of elongation factor EF-2 is the mechanism of diphtheria toxin, not relevant in this case. Glucosylation of Rho family GTPases is the mechanism of C. difficile toxin, which damages the actin cytoskeleton and disrupts cell function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Clindamycin treatment is known to alter gut microbiota and predispose patients to Clostridium difficile infection. C. difficile produces toxins that cause glucosylation of Rho family GTPases, leading to inflammation and diarrhea. Therefore, we can expect to find glucosylation of Rho family GTPases in this patient. The other options are mechanisms of action of different bacterial toxins, not related to C. difficile.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has diarrhea and abdominal pain, suggesting Clostridium difficile infection (CDI). The fact that the patient had recently taken clindamycin, a broad-spectrum antibiotic that can disrupt the normal gut flora, increases the likelihood of CDI. CDI is caused by the release of toxins A and B, which are produced by Clostridium difficile. These toxins cause inflammation of the colon, resulting in diarrhea and abdominal pain. Toxin B is responsible for glucosylation of Rho family GTPases, which ultimately leads to cell death and inflammation. Therefore, (A) is the correct answer. Inactivation of elongation factor EF-2 is caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, ADP-ribosylation of Gs-alpha subunit of G-protein coupled receptors is caused by Vibrio cholerae, and cell membrane degradation by lecithinase is caused by Clostridium perfringens.

Option D is not related to CDI.
